awd_titl_txt: Optimizing the Temperature and Chemical Stability of Fly Ash Aluminosilicate Composites at the Nanoscale
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project centers on understanding and optimizing the temperature and carbonation resistance of low embodied energy cementitious composites for elevated temperature applications, such as fire walls and refractory materials. Use of Portland cement and refractory concrete in society accounts for a sizable amount of energy utilization due to the need for material manufacturing and transportation. Furthermore, Portland cement-based concrete does not perform adequately at elevated temperatures due to decomposition of the main strength-giving constituent, leading to costly repair and replacement. The research to be conducted in this project will promote the use of industrial byproducts in the construction and refractory industries, and therefore encourage further reductions in energy utilization associated with these sectors. The research outcomes of this project will be incorporated into high school teaching modules on materials relating to energy and the environment. In regards to promoting and encouraging underrepresented minorities in science, technology, engineering and mathematics, including young females, this project will enable high school and undergraduate interns to be trained in research during summers and over the academic year.

The objective of this research project is to uncover and optimize the elevated temperature stability and carbonation resistance of chemically-activated cementitious composites, based on aluminosilicate chemistry, using a multifaceted experimental approach. Ambient temperature reaction kinetics and setting times will be investigated using ultrasonic analysis combined with isothermal calorimetry, where calcium-based additives will be utilized to control setting times and short-term mechanical behavior. The molecular structure of chemically-activated metakaolin- and fly ash-based pastes will be elucidated using X-ray pair distribution function analysis and infrared spectroscopy for a range of elevated temperatures, and the project will include the use of in situ carbonation/elevated temperature measurements at synchrotron facilities. Furthermore, given the susceptibility of cementitious materials to dehydration-induced cracking and loss of mechanical properties, the impact of alumina particle and fiber reinforcement on the microstructural (and atomic) behavior of the aluminosilicate composite will be uncovered using synchrotron and lab-based X-ray microtomography. Ultimately this project will generate the fundamental knowledge on the atomic and microstructural behavior of low embodied energy aluminosilicate cements at elevated temperatures, with the long-term aim of integrating this material into applications where conventional concrete quickly degrades due to exposure to high temperatures and aggressive chemicals.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this research project was to develop low CO2 cementitious composites based on alkali-activated technology and uncover and optimize their elevated temperature stability. The composites were based on alkali-activated materials (AAMs) chemistry, and specifically those utilizing metakaolin, a form of calcined clay, due to the current industrial shortages of class F fly ash and the ongoing retirement of coal-fired power plants. Prior to uncovering the high temperature behavior (up to 1000 oC) of these composites, alkali-activated metakaolin (AAMK) pastes were developed that possessed suitable ambient temperature early-age physical and mechanical properties. Then, the high temperature nanoscale and pore structure behavior of these AAMK pastes were determined, and the dimensional stability improved via use of particle and fiber reinforcement.

Concrete based on AAMK has yet to be realized due to several technical hurdles. First, although adequate early age mechanical properties are achievable at ambient temperature, this requires the use of highly concentrated alkali activators. Second, the plate-like particle morphology of rotary-calcined kaolin clay necessitates the use of high water-to-metakaolin ratios, thereby leading to composites with high porosity. In this research project both hurdles were addressed. The addition of calcium to the AAMK pastes in the form of calcium hydroxide (10 wt. % of metakaolin replaced by calcium hydroxide) enabled the use of reduced activator concentrations since it was found that the calcium hydroxide enhanced the alkali activation reaction by promoting metakaolin dissolution and subsequent formation of the strength-giving sodium-alumino-silicate-hydrate (N-A-S-H) gel, as determined using isothermal conduction calorimetry (ICC), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). From an intellectual merit viewpoint, it was discovered that the use of calcium hydroxide in a reduced alkali AAMK led to the formation of an initial calcium-silicate-hydrate-type gel due to the reaction of the calcium hydroxide with the silica in the activator. The formation of this gel was accompanied by the release of additional hydroxide ions as the calcium hydroxide reacted, thereby raising the internal pH of the paste, and enhancing metakaolin dissolution. A broader impact of this component of the research pertained to the lower CO2 emissions associated with the reduced alkali calcium hydroxide-containing AAMK even when accounting for the emissions associated with calcium hydroxide manufacturing. The second technical hurdle facing AAMK concrete, specifically the need for a high water-to-metakaolin ratio, was addressed in this project through utilization of flash-calcined kaolin clay. Analysis of AAMK pastes based on this calcined clay (using a lower water-to-metakaolin ratio, specifically 0.4 or 0.5 instead of the typical 0.9 for rotary-calcined kaolin clay), showed similar ambient and high temperature properties. Differences in reaction kinetics were attributed to the larger particle size distribution of the flash-calcined kaolin clay that was sourced for this project. The results provide preliminary evidence that AAMK concrete manufactured using flash-calcined kaolin clay is feasible.

The next phase of the project focused on uncovering the high temperature behavior of the calcium-containing AAMK pastes. The impact of the calcium addition on high temperature phases that form in AAMK was assessed using in situ synchrotron-based pair distribution function (PDF) analysis combined with standard laboratory characterization techniques. It was discovered that the calcium addition led to enhanced formation of nepheline, a crystalline sodium aluminosilicate phase, and the emergence of small quantities of other calcium-containing crystalline phases. Ongoing analysis of the X-ray PDF data will reveal if calcium is also contained within any amorphous phases present at high temperature (> 800 oC). The pore structure changes invoked due to high temperature exposure were evaluated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) where, in agreement with existing literature, it was found that above approximately 600 oC the AAMK pastes suffered from extensive densification. The impact of fibers (cellulose and polypropylene) and particle reinforcement, in the form of calcined bauxite, on the dimensional stability of the pastes was evaluated using MIP and synchrotron-based X-ray microtomography, where preliminary analysis of the data shows improved stability with the addition of both fibers and calcined bauxite.

All data have been uploaded to Princeton University for long-term storage and access. The experimental results and accompanying data analyses have been documented so far in two peer-reviewed journal articles, with several more pending completion and submission. A graduate PhD thesis from Princeton University will be made publicly available in the summer of 2022 containing all aspects of the project. This project has financially supported the training of two graduate students (one female minority graduate student), three female undergraduate students, and has involved opportunities for outreach including public seminars and conference talks.


Last Modified: 11/26/2021
Modified by: Claire White
